My devotion to the cause is not lessened by the dishonest actions of Planned Parenthood‚Äôs political arm, but I am disappointed by the underhanded nature of these endorsements and the complete blackballing of candidates other than the one the DSCC hand-picked for Maine.

source: Bre "Bee Kay" Kidman for U.S. Senate, 2020
text: Sara‚Äôs tweet is a really weird way to say ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt support #M4A or the #GND and I took a maximum contribution from ICE‚Äôs landlord in Portland.‚Äù If elected, I promise to fight for: -Medicare For All: universal healthcare delivered in a way that ensures everyone has equal access to quality providers regardless of income. -The Green New Deal: a path to create social and economic justice using an opportunity for the United States to be an innovative leader in the race to address climate change. -The end of ICE: literally abolishing ICE. source: Bre "Bee Kay" Kidman for U.S. Senate, 2020
text: Like I have been saying: ‚ÄúMaine‚Äôs ethics watchdog on Wednesday unanimously found House Speaker Sara Gideon‚Äôs use of a partially corporate-funded committee to reimburse herself for two 2016 political donations violated state law.‚Äù The FEC complaint still pending deals with the fact that ‚ÄúGideon‚Äôs committee took 60 percent of its money from business sources between 2014 and early 2019 that are allowed to contribute to state campaigns but not federal ones‚Äù and then used that money in federal races. The FEC complaint will be delayed by the FEC‚Äôs lack of quorum. It‚Äôs possible that it could be heard during the general election. We cannot afford to fight Susan Collins with someone who has already broken the law by funneling corporate money into federal races.  Please share this widely. (Source: https://bangordailynews.com/2019/10/30/politics/maine-ethics-watchdog-fines-sara-gideons-political-committee-over-contributions/)

source: Bre "Bee Kay" Kidman for U.S. Senate, 2020
text: ‚Äú‚ÄòI am not taking a dime in corporate PAC money during this campaign because it will always be clear who I am working for in the U.S. Senate: the people of Maine,‚Äô‚Äù Gideon says in her latest ad. But Gideon has accepted tens of thousands of dollars from so-called ‚Äòleadership PACs‚Äô run by Democratic members of Congress that, in turn, accept donations from corporate PACs.‚Äù We get enough misrepresentation from Collins. We don‚Äôt need it from a Democratic nominee. Share this post and tag our page if you‚Äôre tired of being lied to.

source: Bre "Bee Kay" Kidman for U.S. Senate, 2020
text: If you haven‚Äôt heard the three candidates in the primary speak yet, Steve Collins‚Äô piece in the Sun Journal includes video of all of us. At the end of Gideon‚Äôs video, you‚Äôll hear her say that 97% of her contributions came from donations under $100. This is a misrepresentation. 42% of her total money was from contributions under $200. I should have made her clarify. Next time I‚Äôll do better. Maine deserves better than a candidate who can‚Äôt answer a direct question honestly. We already have a Senator for that. Maine deserves a relentless truth-teller. It‚Äôs not an easy or popular thing to be... but I‚Äôm trying.

source: Bre "Bee Kay" Kidman for U.S. Senate, 2020

And allies, for ourselves.

source: Bre "Bee Kay" Kidman for U.S. Senate, 2020
text: Saturday night, I drove a van containing an amazing group of Mainers down to Sunday‚Äôs #ReclaimTheCourt rally at SCOTUS. I stood alongside survivors and allies as we claimed space that rightfully belongs to us and demanded to be heard. This morning, I‚Äôm headed back to SCOTUS in hopes I‚Äôll be able to get in for oral argument on cases of absolutely pivotal importance to the LGBTQ+ rights movement.  If not, I will stand with other LGBTQ+ people, all of us waiting to hear what questions the Supreme Court asks when they try to decide if we are worth protecting from discrimination. Someday, LGBTQ+ people will have enough decision making power to ensure that the value of our lives stops being batted around like a political pawn by cisgender heterosexual people who have no idea what our lives are like. I have a lot of privilege as a white queer person with a relatively stable source of income in a state with explicit protections on the basis of sexual orientation and gender identity... but that could change if I were to leave Maine or accept a job with the federal government. On Sunday, I stood in solidarity with survivors. Today, I will stand in solidarity with LGBTQ+ people. I stand alongside my communities because these battles are mine, too. If I am elected, I will keep fighting. Once we are in the room, once we claim our seats at the table, they won‚Äôt be able to decide without us anymore.

source: Bre "Bee Kay" Kidman for U.S. Senate, 2020
text: One year ago today, I spoke at a rally outside the Supreme Court, asking Susan Collins in front of thousands of people if survivors of sexual assault mattered to her. Then I went to her office to meet with a staffer who could only tell me ‚Äúshe‚Äôs got a lot to consider‚Äù when I asked what my senator was taking into account. One year ago today, I sat outside the Hart building chain smoking and trying to shake the feeling that there was nothing any of the other survivors I was traveling with or I could do to meaningfully influence our representation. One year ago today, I felt defeated before the vote was even announced, felt my insides twisting, felt like there had to be a better way. When I heard about the Be A Hero fund, I got a flutter in my chest. ‚ÄúMaybe I could... No, that‚Äôs ridiculous.‚Äù Over the next month, I started asking myself why it‚Äôs so ridiculous that someone with federal policy experience, a law degree, and a life that actually reflects median-income Mainers‚Äô struggles would decide to run. I ran out of reasons not to pretty quickly. One year ago today, I took a stand and then realized that we need to go further if we want things to change. Tomorrow, I‚Äôm traveling to the Supreme Court again for another rally with #ReclaimTheCourt... but this time I‚Äôm done feeling powerless. I am in this race to reclaim our voice in our government. Are you with me?

source: Bre "Bee Kay" Kidman for U.S. Senate, 2020
text: I support the Green New Deal as a set of guiding principles for the work we need to do to address the climate crisis.  Governor Mills‚Äô non-binding unspecific promise to get to zero emissions by 2045 doesn‚Äôt go far enough. We need to jump on this opportunity for American innovation. The challenge of zero emissions in ten years is the kind of pressure that allows American ingenuity to flourish and creates opportunities for us all to prosper in a world fueled by clean energy. I believe we are up to the challenge of making green energy America‚Äôs next great economic success story!

text: If you want a Senator who‚Äôs unfiltered (and who hasn‚Äôt taken money from insurance and pharmaceutical companies), look no further.  HEALTHCARE IS A HUMAN RIGHT. When we leave healthcare in the hands of private corporations (whose LEGAL ROLE is to increase shareholder profit every quarter), we entrust the preservation of our lives to people who care most about getting the best deal for their shareholders‚Äînot the people they cover. Maine deserves a Senator who won‚Äôt equivocate about ensuring that the American people are getting the best deal. No doublespeak‚Äîjust bold advocacy for people over profit margins.

source: Bre "Bee Kay" Kidman for U.S. Senate, 2020
text: ICYMI: Sara Gideon used her leadership PAC to reimburse herself for contributions she made in her own name, which is a federal offense. Warnings against doing that appear literally every time you donate online. The effect of that was to funnel direct corporate contributions (which are allowed in Maine state races but illegal in federal elections‚Äîhence the existence of corporate PACs) into a federal race. Which is also illegal. So much for that promise she keeps making to end big money in politics. Campaign finance laws exist to keep the electoral process fair. We can‚Äôt trust candidates who violate these laws to represent us faithfully. The fact that both candidates with a lot of money are doing it doesn‚Äôt make it okay.

source: Bre "Bee Kay" Kidman for U.S. Senate, 2020
text: While mental illness generally reflects a break with reality, violent white nationalist rhetoric IS our reality.

source: Bre "Bee Kay" Kidman for U.S. Senate, 2020
text: The fact that Sara Gideon ‚Äúdidn‚Äôt know‚Äù it‚Äôs illegal to funnel direct corporate money into federal races doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs okay that she did it. The fact that she ‚Äúdidn‚Äôt know‚Äù it‚Äôs illegal to funnel direct corporate money into federal races means she doesn‚Äôt understand the issue well enough to fight it.  Maine deserves a candidate who is ready to fight corruption in politics‚Äînot just pay lip service to the idea of eliminating corporate PAC money. Indirect corporate money influencing campaigns is every bit as much a threat to our democracy as dark money and is significantly more harmful than openly disclosed corporate PAC money. Burying the problem so the voters can‚Äôt see it is antithetical to a functioning democratic republic. We deserve better.

source: Bre "Bee Kay" Kidman for U.S. Senate, 2020
text: On Sunday, Gideon spoke about not listening to people who sow seeds of division in the party. By violating campaign finance laws, she has sown the seeds herself. The division is between those who follow the law and run campaigns ethically and those who believe that the rules don‚Äôt apply to them. Ask yourself how much you are willing to sweep under the rug for party unity... and then ask yourself if that‚Äôs the kind of representation Maine deserves.

source: Bre "Bee Kay" Kidman for U.S. Senate, 2020
text: ‚Äú‚ÄòThere is no more convenient revolution than making yourself heard,‚Äô Kidman says. ‚ÄòBecause if we can‚Äôt get a foot in the door now, the revolution to come is a lot scarier. I don‚Äôt think it gets easier.‚Äô‚Äù

source: Bre "Bee Kay" Kidman for U.S. Senate, 2020,Christina Iris
text: Thanks to Christina Iris for getting Sunday‚Äôs speech on video.  Process matters. I don't think this is what they were expecting to hear, but the response was overwhelmingly positive. We can decide who we want to be, as a party, and as a country.
